p: Melanization-based mechanisms that inactivate malaria parasites exist in nature, as do resistant mechanisms in the parasite, providing insight into parasite evolutionary responses. In nature, there is a melanization pathway by which pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) bind to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), activating a cascade of reactions culminating in large-scale melanin synthesis and encapsulation of the parasite in a melanin coat ( Cerenius et al., 2008). Parasite resistance responses include: i) breaking down melanin, or ii) interfering with melanin activation or synthesis pathways. Yassine et al. have documented a mechanism whereby two key regulators of malaria melanization in An. gambiae (TEP1 and CLIPA8) are deactivated ( Yassine et al., 2012). Mutations could occur on the PAMPs, preventing the PRRs from binding to them.
